fishData.name: Clownfish
fishData.description: Bright orange with white stripes, commonly found in coral reefs. Known for their symbiotic relationship with sea anemones.

fishData.name: Blue Tang
fishData.description: A vibrant blue fish with a yellow tail, often found in coral reefs. Famous for its role in 'Finding Nemo'.

fishData.name: Lionfish
fishData.description: Venomous fish with long, spiky fins. Native to Indo-Pacific, now invasive in Atlantic reefs.

fishData.name: Great White Shark
fishData.description: Large predatory shark found in coastal waters across the globe. Known for its power and size.

fishData.name: Sailfish
fishData.description: Fastest fish in the ocean, known for its long, slender bill and sail-like dorsal fin.

fishData.name: Mackerel
fishData.description: Streamlined fish found in temperate and tropical seas, popular as food due to its oily flesh.

fishData.name: Tuna
fishData.description: Large, fast-swimming fish found in warm seas, valued both commercially and for sport fishing.

fishData.name: Anglerfish
fishData.description: Deep-sea fish with a bioluminescent lure to attract prey. Notable for its terrifying appearance.

fishData.name: Moray Eel
fishData.description: Snake-like carnivorous fish living in crevices of reefs and rocks in both shallow and deep sea.

fishData.name: Parrotfish
fishData.description: Colorful reef fish known for their beak-like teeth used to scrape algae from coral.

fishData.name: Barracuda
fishData.description: Long, predatory fish with sharp teeth, found in tropical and subtropical oceans.

fishData.name: Flying Fish
fishData.description: Known for their ability to glide above water to escape predators using wing-like pectoral fins.

fishData.name: Cod
fishData.description: Cold water fish known for its commercial importance in Europe and North America.

fishData.name: Swordfish
fishData.description: Large predatory fish with a long, flat bill, known for speed and sport fishing.

fishData.name: Herring
fishData.description: Small, oily fish that swim in large schools in the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans.

fishData.name: Grouper
fishData.description: Large bottom-dwelling fish often found in warm seas. Popular in commercial fishing.

fishData.name: Snapper
fishData.description: Found in tropical and subtropical regions, these fish are often brightly colored and reef-dwelling.

fishData.name: Sea Bass
fishData.description: Common name for several species found in shallow warm seas, known for their culinary value.

fishData.name: Pufferfish
fishData.description: Inflates its body as a defense mechanism. Some species contain deadly toxins.

fishData.name: Tilapia
fishData.description: Freshwater fish that can live in brackish waters. Widely farmed and consumed worldwide.

fishData.name: Salmon
fishData.description: Born in freshwater, migrate to sea, and return to spawn. Valued for its high Omega-3 content.

fishData.name: Eel
fishData.description: Long, snake-like fish found in both freshwater and marine environments. Some species migrate between them.

fishData.name: Hammerhead Shark
fishData.description: Recognized by its unique hammer-shaped head; found in warm ocean waters.

fishData.name: Tiger Shark
fishData.description: A large shark with stripes along its body, known for eating a wide variety of prey.

fishData.name: Bull Shark
fishData.description: Aggressive and can live in both salt and freshwater; often found in rivers and shallow waters.

fishData.name: Mako Shark
fishData.description: Fastest species of shark; known for its speed and agility in the water.

fishData.name: Thresher Shark
fishData.description: Distinguished by its long, whip-like tail used to stun prey.

fishData.name: Nurse Shark
fishData.description: Generally slow-moving and docile; often seen resting on the sea floor.

fishData.name: Whale Shark
fishData.description: The largest known shark and fish species; a gentle giant that feeds on plankton.

fishData.name: Goblin Shark
fishData.description: A rare deep-sea shark with a long, flat snout and protruding jaws.

fishData.name: Basking Shark
fishData.description: The second-largest living shark; filter-feeder like the whale shark.

fishData.name: Blacktip Shark
fishData.description: Commonly found in coastal tropical and subtropical waters; named for black tips on fins.

fishData.name: Blue Shark
fishData.description: Sleek, fast swimmer with a distinct blue coloration; found in deep waters.

fishData.name: Sand Tiger Shark
fishData.description: Has a fearsome appearance with protruding teeth, but is generally not aggressive.

fishData.name: Lemon Shark
fishData.description: Named for its yellow-brown coloring; often found in shallow coastal waters.

fishData.name: Port Jackson Shark
fishData.description: A bottom-dwelling shark from Australia, recognized by its harness-like markings.

fishData.name: Cookiecutter Shark
fishData.description: Small deep-sea shark that gouges round plugs of flesh from larger animals.

fishData.name: Greenland Shark
fishData.description: Lives in the cold deep waters of the North Atlantic; extremely slow-growing and long-lived.

fishData.name: Wobbegong
fishData.description: A type of carpet shark with a flattened body and ornate patterns for camouflage.

fishData.name: Zebra Shark
fishData.description: Has stripes when young that turn into spots as it matures; found in Indo-Pacific reefs.

fishData.name: Frilled Shark
fishData.description: An ancient, eel-like shark with frilly gills; rarely seen due to deep-sea habitat.

fishData.name: Sawshark
fishData.description: Characterized by a long snout edged with teeth, resembling a saw.

fishData.name: Angel Shark
fishData.description: Flattened body similar to a ray; hides in sand and ambushes prey.
